story.title: Viking Q&A #VikingQ

author.name: British Museum
author.bio: A museum of the world, for the world.

image.caption: We're here with #VikingExhibition Curator Gareth Williams for our live Q&A #VikingQ http://t.co/cdUdzzKhsF

quote.text: We're here with #VikingExhibition Curator Gareth Williams for our live Q&A #VikingQ http://t.co/cdUdzzKhsF
@britishmuseum Did the Vikings come from different countries apart from Sweden, Denmark and Norway? Sam Yr 4 #VikingQandA
Yes - they came from all over Scandinavia and around the Baltic. They weren't a single people (1/2)
Viking is not so much an ethnic label as a job description (2/2) #VikingQ
@britishmuseum #VikingQ are there many examples of the standard-weight silver arm bands found outside Dublin?
Most of the arm rings come from outside Dublin. Dublin had lots of silver coins which aren't found much elsewhere in Ireland (1/2) #VikingQ
Viking silver jewellery was rare in Dublin but is found elsewhere in Ireland and around the Irish Sea in England, Scotland etc (2/2)
Early raids just involved a few ships and tens rather than hundreds of men. Later armies were much bigger (1/2) #VikingQ
From the 830s onwards we hear of fleets of hundreds of ships and thousands of men and this is confirmed by recent archaeological finds (2/2)
Not as far as we know. Viking siege warfare was pretty basic. There is one account that could refer to a ballista but this is disputed.
Some Viking camps have produced large numbers of gaming pieces, suggesting that Viking warriors enjoyed playing boardgames and gambling.
@britishmuseum When the Vikings raided Lindisfarne, did they capture and trade monks using them as slaves? Emily Yr 4 #VikingQandA
We don't know for certain about Lindisfarne, but certainly they took monks as slaves from other monasteries so it is likely #VikingQ
@britishmuseum were the Jomsvikings real or legendary? #VikingQandA
Most of what we know about the Jomsvikings is legendary, but there may be a core of fact behind the legend (1/2) #VikingQ
Jomsborg (home of the Jomsvikings) has been identified with the town of Wolin in Poland (2/2) #VikingQ
Dear @britishmuseum do we know anything about what kind of music the Vikings made/listened to? #VikingQ
We have parts of some surviving musical instruments including lyres (small harps), pan pipes, bone flutes and wooden pipes (1/2) #VikingQ
We don't have any detail of the music itself, although we do know that music sometimes accompanied poetry and was also used in rituals (2/2)
@britishmuseum Did viking ships ever go round Cape Horn, and up into the Pacific?
Not as far as we know. But if someone finds a Viking ship in the Pacific, we may have to rethink! #VikingQ
It's not normally very pointy. It's called a boss and it extends out of the shield to protect the hand holding the shield. #VikingQ
@britishmuseum Is it true Swedish vikings were more traders than warriors?
Some were traders, others were warriors, others were craftsmen, most were farmers. #VikingQ
@britishmuseum #VikingQ I am loving these questions!
#VikingExhibition #VikingQ How do you begin approaching a subject surrounded by so many [cultural and academic] cliches and misconceptions?
Very carefully! The exhibition focuses on themes where there is something new to say because of new interpretations and new finds #VikingQ
I'm trying to brew authentic mead. Are there any ancient Viking hints or tips? #VikingsQ
No authentic recipes. On a practical level I recommend wine yeast rather than beer yeast and add the honey gradually for a stronger brew.
Who is the most prominent female Viking? #VikingsQ
We don't hear as much as we might about Viking women. One of the most famous is Gunnhild, wife of Eric Bloodaxe (1/2) #VikingQ
Gunnhild was supposedly an evil witch from Arctic Norway. After her husband's death she ruled Norway through her sons (2/2) #VikingQ
Eric Bloodaxe is one of the best known kings but he was a bit of a loser. He was kicked out of Norway, then Northumbria, then killed. (1/2)
The most powerful Viking king was Cnut. He conquered England in 1016, then became King of Denmark, then conquered Norway in 1028. (2/2)
#VikingQ what was the farthest place from their homeland that Vikings ventured to? From tash
The Vikings reached eastern Canada, Morocco, and Central Asia. Similar distances in different directions #VikingQ
The longest boat is just over 37 metres long. Come and see it at the #VikingExhibition! Most were much smaller #VikingQ
@britishmuseum #VikingQ Can you give me an interesting fact about Viking beards?
Beards were not all the same in the Viking age and different Vikings had nicknames derived from their beards. (1/2) #VikingQ
Two of the most famous are Svein Forkbeard, King of the Danes and Sihtric Silkbeard, King of Dublin. (2/2)
Got a student researching Viking museums/exhibitions. Which inspired you/ is your favourite? Apart from @britishmuseum obviously :) #VikingQ
Lots of fantastic Viking museums. I have a soft spot for the Jorvik Centre in York, which I visited as a teenager when it first opened (1/2)
My favourite though would have to be the Viking Ship Museum in Oslo. The Gokstad ship is so beautiful, I want to marry it (2/2) #VikingQ
@britishmuseum thank you for your kind words! You have made the Vikings of JORVIK in York very happy in our 30th year! #JORVIK30
#VikingQ from Ledbury Primary School: Could all Vikings read and write using runes?
No, not all Vikings could read runes, but in this period most people in other cultures couldn't read either. #VikingQ
#VikingQ from Ledbury Primary School: What did the Vikings eat and drink?
They ate a lot of porridge, sometimes with meat and vegetables mixed in. They had root vegetables, onions and leeks (1/2) #VikingQ
They ate meat and fish but had no refrigerators, so they salted and dried meat to preserve it. They drank mead (from honey) and ale (2/2)
#VikingQ from Acorns Primary School: Can you settle the myth as to whether they did or didn't have horns on their helmets?
The myth of the horned helmets was invented in the 19th century. Vikings as Victorians thought they should have been, not as they were!
#VikingQ from Darell Primary School: How did the Vikings know the Saxons?
They had contact through trade before the first Viking raids in the 780s. They then raided England for many years, then settled (1/2)
After the Viking settlement, Vikings and Saxons sometimes continued to fight but also lived alongside each other fairly peacefully (2/2)
#VikingQ from Ledbury Primary School: Did girls ever go on raids? What jobs did they do?
Viking women are sometimes recorded as travelling with raiding armies. Finds from Viking military camps show a female presence (1/2)
Spindle whorls & loom weights show that women made cloth in these Viking camps. Viking sorceresses also accompanied armies sometimes (2/2)
#VikingQ from Hall School Wimbledon: Did the Vikings have any sense of hygiene?
Compared to the Arabs, the Vikings were pretty grubby. One Arab traveller described them as 'the filthiest of God's creatures' (1/2)
However, combs are very common from Viking sites and we also have nail files and scoops for getting wax out of Vikings' ears (2/2) #VikingQ
Thanks to #VikingExhibition Curator Gareth Williams for answering lots of your questions! #VikingQ

Great tweets from @britishmuseum right now answering questions on #Vikings !
Wow. @britishmuseum 's #VikingQ is excellent!
